@investing・88  4-week report and look-ahead

4-week highlights:
-  Minimum fixes, no major bugs since launch, indicating a solid technical foundation
- Incredible returns from top performing miners
- One of the fastest growing subnets, indicating strong demand for staking strategies from the community

Short-term roadmap:
- Rolling allocation view coming online in the next couple days
- Simulating block-level precision with limited hourly market data
- Introducing a rolling window for score calculation, to accommodate the current short-term nature of the dtao market. Window length will gradually increase as dtao matures in the coming months and years
- Implementing market return as the score benchmark baseline
- Misc UI improvements per @Sticker.z above
- Major roadmap items remain the same and in parallel development
The score rolling window will initially start at 30 days. Would appreciate feedback as this will affect all miners

I see a bright future here. 
You guys are delivering every seconds. Very nice, I like it

Oopp looks like I got some work to do. 

Thanks for the feedback everyone. 💪🏻
What does this mean exactly? Like score is only calculated every 30 days?
I suppose it's about moving average of the past 30 day's score. Make sense

@InfiniTao But in that case, you will change the scoring logic too? After all, for such a moving score should be calculated not for the entire life of the miner, but for each day separately. In my opinion, this will be very different from the current logic, since it will turn the strategies into "one-day" ones. That is, it will be necessary to achieve maximum scoring only within a day, and not in a prolonged manner (I can't find the word)

As I have suggested, extending the incentive period to 30 days will greatly affect new miners. They will suffer a lot even if the immue period is only 3 days 😄 I think it would be more reasonable to leave the period as 1 week than 1 month, or at most half a month.

If a 30 day window means only the last 30 days performance matters, then I think that’s going in the wrong direction. Long-term management means I won’t be having gains every month, so I don’t want to only be rewarded with emissions part of the year (even if it technically averages out). Smoothing the emissions ala the current system is still optimal because it already rewards those who’ve managed well for the long-term. 

A 30 day window just incentivizes degen behavior even more where you register with risk allocations and try to beat out the people that are actually using responsible strategies

> The score rolling window will initially start at 30 days
The score will only take the last 30 days into account. It’s not a move average so no change in the scoring logic. New miners won’t be affected. If anything it may help them

A rolling window is needed even in long-term asset management, since performance in the distant past is less relevant to future performance. Internally we use a 1 year window to evaluate our own strategies in stocks and forex.

Right now dtao is inherently short-term. It’s a market in its infancy. People speculate, resulting in incredible volatility. We’ve all seen subnets doing 10x, 100x in a span of a few days or even hours. It’s extreme in many cases even by crypto standards. If a strategy happens to catch a 100x, whether by luck or skills, it can reap the reward almost indefinitely. Obviously such a strategy will become less useful as time goes by.

That’s why we decided to implement a rolling window. If it's luck, the miner gets rewarded for a relatively short time period. I don't think anyone can complain. If it's skills, the miner will be able to keep finding the next 100x and stay on top. More power to them. In any case, The subnet will provide more value to end users when we start packaging it as a service/product
I am feeling so silly as I don't understand the codebase - is synapse between validator and miner for pinging?

Consider this scenario: a great miner consistently makes money in 10 of 12 months. Maybe something crazy like 100% per month. 

Then, for 2 months their portfolio is flat or negative. They would get dereg. That is a serious flaw, no?

Sure, they can reg again but all of the progress in managing the fund is reset and that rolling window increasing to 1 year sometime in the future wouldn’t help because all history of success was lost. They could have a 10,000 TAO balance and be treated the same as a fresh miner that gambled it all in the first week.  

This promotes degen behaviors to catch the latest pump and collect emissions for the month rather than professional portfolio management.
In most subnets yes. In our case we have a different design – out of necessity, where validators and miners do not ping each other

Correct. In this hypothetical scenario, the miner’s 10 month performance in the past no longer provides value in the fast moving dtao market.

It’s a phenomenon sometimes called alpha decay in the quant world. A strategy can perform well out of the gate for a period of time, and inevitably becomes useless as time goes by, when others players discover and catch up with the same strategy. We’ve seen it time and time again in our own strategies. It’s perhaps the toughest game, with the best and brightest minds in the competition

> This promotes degen behaviors to catch the latest pump and collect emissions for the month rather than professional portfolio management.
Risky behaviors that only catch the pump without planning for the dump will most likely result in a high risk% and low MAR, therefore a low score

I didn't know about that.
Very good tactics

I don't think @iztali is talking about alpha decay here. With long-term strategies, there are natural seasonal or cyclical patterns where a strategy may be better during some periods while worse during others. This is especially prevalent for long-only funds since shorting/market-neutral strats are not a thing in dTAO. So I can certainly see their argument and tend to agree with it

That being said, with dTAO in its infancy and being such a fast-moving market this may not be as much of a concern. Underlying market dynamics will likely change extremely quickly so past performance is particularly noisy

Good point. It will likely take years for cyclical patterns to emerge in the dtao market, one form of which could be the infamous 4-year halving cycle of BTC. We will closely monitor market dynamics as well as performance metrics from all strategies. The rolling window length will gradually increase when necessary, as mentioned previously.

We are confident in the long-term that miners will optimize their portfolios with reduced covariance, minimized cyclical effects, and always stay on the elusive efficient frontier.

May the frontier be with you.

I think you're @Hazard making a very important philosophical mistake in understanding the principle of this subnet, evaluating its assets (subnets) as a **stock** portfolio, while the whole logic of evaluation is closer to a **bond** portfolio (personally, I fully support this evaluation system).

In the first case, DCA is a really promising strategy, in the second case it will lead to too frequent rebalancing. The "stock" market is a market of impulses. The "bond" market is a market of precise calculations and optimums. And since the incentive mechanism here is aimed at long-term investments (long-term portfolio retention), then the second approach is needed.

This does not mean that there is no place for averaging here, you just should not do it mechanically, but only when all your calculations say that now is really the best moment for this.
And since it is the best, it does not make much difference (except for slippage) whether your scoring will reset or not, since it will start growing again due to a well-chosen moment, but just for a different portfolio composition.

Haha philosophy is not involved in this subnet. Only math. DCA works only if the underlying instrument goes up in price. It also assumes you have cash in hand. If your portfolio is fully allocated, inevitably it means you’re cashing out from one subnet and DCA into another, which is just active rebalancing.

Also, DCA usually means a fixed Dollar or Tao amount on a regular basis, so you’ll need some math to convert the fixed Tao amount into percentage, since the portfolio value is ever changing

We are still in the process of optimizing the incentive mechanism, balancing short-term vs long-term, in order for our miners to realize their full potential and provide most value to our eventual end users and investors.

In addition, most subnets still lack liquidity. The market simply can not sustain mass adoption of concentrated strategies at the moment.

The business structure will likely be a mixture of partnership with institutional investors and subscription plans for retailers. It will involve processed composite strategies, not raw allocations from individual miners.

For stocks, which will be rolled out in the not so distant future, the process can potentially be accelerated, leveraging experiences gathered from the dtao phase, on top of a fully matured market.

Since price impact is such an issue, it is more difficult to multiply a large balance than a small one. Smaller balance miners can play for low liquidity subnets for small gains, while large balance miners are stuck fighting for the same subnets at lower percentages. 

Month to month this will force out miners that have performed well. There needs to be some sort of moving average to account for historical performance

Score only considers daily% not overall yield%, so it does not discriminate against large or small accounts. It only requires consistent performance over time. The rolling window is a simple moving average as far as daily% is concerned

Hello all! 👋 

I propose a discussion.

In my opinion, it is better to simply make a delay than copy protection.

In the first case, miners will not simply copy each other effectively.

In the second case, if you introduce a penalty for copying, then when all miners understand the nature of Tao, only the first one to register will receive a reward and a simple race for the first block will begin.

And imagine. There is a really very, very limited set of promising assets on the market (be it Tao or stocks). And if 10 miners understand this at the same time, does this mean that the 10th understands it worse than the first?

And the last. There are only a little over 100 subnets to choose from in the bittensor. Working with shares, we are simply doomed to frequent copying. It's like Neo's choice between the blue and red pill. Everyone chose the red one, but everyone went their own way.
Great points. It's definitely a decision that won't be taken lightly
Thank you for hearing me.

It could be a combination of both a delay and copy prevention. On one hand we want to ensure all miners get rewarded fairly, and on the other hand we want to make an attempt to promote inspiration and collaboration among our miner community
I agree. I just highlighted a few pitfalls.🤝
For reference, internally we use a 1-year rolling window to evaluate our own strategies in stocks

I think a copy prevention mechanism in this context would be extremely counterproductive for the quality of miner submissions. Since solutions are a vector of weights, "good" strategies (local optima) tend to be very close to the "best" solution (global optima). 

For example suppose the best solution for today was `{1:0.5, 88:0.5}`, then any solution such as `{1:0.49, 88:0.51}, {1:0.51, 88:0.49}` will have very similar scores/performance/risk. If you enforce a distance penalty, this redefines the "best" solution as one that is orthogonal to the actual optima we care about. End result can be a bunch of mediocre or bad strategies but which are novel/unconventional

A delay on dashboard would be helpful, but better would be not displaying them at all imo. For the subnet's goals, I'm assuming these strategies would be eventually monetized on the frontend app for investors? If everything is already publicly available, what's the purpose of the app?

In addition as the subnet grows and dTAO matures (or we expand to other asset classes like equities), I would personally not be comfortable revealing strategies this publicly due to risk of alpha decay - and I think most serious quants would feel the same

I for one oppose both copy prevention and a delay. Transparency promotes innovation, so the goal shouldn’t be to hide miner edge just so they can profit more. 

I enjoy having the leaderboard. I’ve been using it to create composite strategies for personal alpha investing and also market analysis.

Incentivizing both good and novel strategies while discouraging copying would be essential for long-term success. Transparency of results in this context actually severely slows or halts innovation due to a misalignment of incentives. As a somewhat hyperbolic example - suppose RenTech decides to start posting their live portfolio holdings. One could try to analyze and reverse-engineer the logic behind their holdings and improve upon it, but the vast majority of funds will likely simply copy them as the marginal benefit from doing so is low. 

With a delay, this is helpful though with the long-term portfolio management focus (relatively infrequent rebalancing) of the subnet - it seems difficult to determine an appropriate delay time. Generally speaking, be very careful allocating into newer, lower liquidity subnets. Slippage can really cost you

To limit single asset allocation, we are considering an API strat submission rule. Basic requirement is minimum 3 subnets. Very simple:

```
n = 3
st = {k:v for k,v in strat.items() if k} # exclude subnet 0
if len(st) < n or max(st.values()) / min(st.values()) > len(st): api.reject()
```
The number (n = 3) can be adjusted up or down, but the gist remains. This has been a concern since day 1 but not a major issue so far. Would appreciate feedback

I was just browsing through this channel to see if copy prevention is a thing for this subnet. 
Came across this message - thought I'd respond.
> For example suppose the best solution for today was `{1:0.5, 88:0.5`}, then any solution such as `{1:0.49, 88:0.51}, {1:0.51, 88:0.49}` will have very similar scores/performance/risk. If you enforce a distance penalty, this redefines the "best" solution as one that is orthogonal to the actual optima we care about. End result can be a bunch of mediocre or bad strategies but which are novel/unconventional
This is a good point, and it's something we realized on SN10 a while back. Thought I'd explain the workaround we ended up using - might be useful here.

First, a quick breakdown of sn10:
The goal of miners on sn10 is to output asset allocation suggestions across different pool types (ethereum lending pools, alpha token pools, etc.), and the miner who consistently outputs good asset allocations with good returns is scored more highly.
```
# pseudocode
all_miner_outputs = {
  `0`: {'a': 100, b: 500, .... } # miner_uid: {'pool0_uid': amount_allocated_to_pool0, 'pool1_uid': amount_allocated_to_pool1, ...}}
  `1`: {'a': 200, b: 100, .... }
  ...
}
``` 
allocations are scored after 24hrs. 

when we score miners one of the first parts of the process is:
1. calculate the returns of the allocations, and then use that information to normalize their scores. 
2. then, we compare them to see if any of them are very similar to one another. if they are, then the miner that responded the slowest gets penalized. The more similar occurances the more a miner gets penalized.
this is basically all we used to do before we incorporated binning.
now, (as @hamlet pointed out) this in itself is bad because it incentivizes miners to output sub-par allocations, since they'd be afraid to be whacked by the similarity checker.

to address this we: right after (1), we would assign miners to their own bins based on their scores, and *then* apply the similarity penalties, and then normalize their final score to be *within* the score range of their assigned bins (this is visualized in the provided graphic). The result scoring mechanism:
- disincentivizes miners providing similar allocations
- doesn't overincentivize sub-par allocations
- heavily incentivizes that top miners try and output optimal allocations.

ps. the "top miner boost" mechanism is something we had to remove shortly after because the way it was implemented was buggy - but we are planning on bringing it back in a slightly different form in our next update.

@investing・88 Miners:

We are considering a second layer in the global DEC, based on miner scores.

The point again is emissions must reflect value. If miners are inactive and/or underperforming as is the current case, it’s hard to justify emissions.

Score is an objective measure of portfolio performance across all assets. Roughly and empirically speaking, a double-digit score is considered acceptable and tradable, while triple-digit and beyond are considered exceptional. Following is the tentative formula:

```
all = sum(scores) / 256
top = max(scores) / sum(scores) / (positive_score_count + 1)^0.5
dec2 = 1 - max(all, top)
if dec2 > 0: validator.scores[0] = sum(scores) * dec2 / (1 – dec2)
```

In plain English, to avoid dec2, it requires a baseline combined score of 256 from all miners, or an average of 1, which is more than reasonable, while an outsized top score can counter the effect. The baseline number can be adjusted over time. 

Would appreciate feedback as always.

Working code that calculates Tao -> Alpha allocation:
```
t, n = 100, 1 # 100 Tao allocated to Subnet 1
import bittensor as bt, re
st = bt.Subtensor().get_metagraph_info(n)
ain = float(re.sub(r'[^0-9.]', '', str(st.alpha_in)))
tin = float(re.sub(r'[^0-9.]', '', str(st.tao_in)))
a = ain - ain * tin / (tin + t)
print(f'Tao {t} -> Alpha {a}')
```
